title:
Reclaiming the Commons:

Pathways to a Post-Growth Future from the Global South
affiliations: National Law School of India University

detail.title:
Reclaiming the Commons:

Pathways to a Post-Growth Future from the Global South

publicationDetails.detailsText: A Report submitted to Special Rapporteur on Extreme Poverty and Human Rights, Olivier De Schutter

detail.abstract: Are human rights evolving in such a way that the enormous challenges posed by climate change is coming within its ambit? In this report, we argue that such an evolution may not be natural. But, there is great value to facilitate such an evolution. One key aspect would be to bring 'commoning' as an agenda of human rights. Human rights instruments are typically seen as state's obligation to citizens. Where human rights violations are taking place, it is the state which is brought under the scanner. However, from this state-centered world view, we have arrived a state-decentered world after globalization. The global challenges posed today, namely inequality, climate change etc, also cant be dealt with through a state-centred old world view. On the other hand, commons have remained an alternative way of managing resources compared to private property arrangements and state-owned public property. Both in private property arrangements and public property arrangements, the worldview of state-centered prevails. This paper is providing a road map on what would be the model of governance when commons are brought to the agenda of poverty reduction.

title: Climate Reductionism or Possibilism: Exploring Whether Climate Change is Driving Gentrification in South St. Petersburg
affiliations: Florida State University, Florida State University, Florida State University, University of Illinois Chicago and Florida State University

detail.title: Climate Reductionism or Possibilism: Exploring Whether Climate Change is Driving Gentrification in South St. Petersburg
detail.abstract: This paper uses a hybrid case study and grounded theory methodology to understand how professionals in the affordable housing space are addressing the threat of climate gentrification in South Saint Petersburg, Florida. This challenges the way we think about climate gentrification as not prompted by a singular cause but rather through a complex system of housing market pressures. Our results show that the effects of migration, geography, regional characteristics, and the growth of the rental market may overshadow the effects of climate gentrification. Interviewees indicate the gentrification pressure facing south St. Petersburg is much more complex and larger in scale than local leaders are equipped to handle.

title: Comparing Bank Risk Measures
affiliations: Risk Control Limited

detail.title: Comparing Bank Risk Measures
detail.abstract:
Bank counter-party risk became a major issue for many market participants during the recent financial crisis. The risk was complex and involved multiple dimensions. Fluctuations in risk occurred not just as the financial state of banks fluctuated but also because the capacity and willingness of sovereigns to rescue banks changed over time.

Major corporates, non-bank financial firms and public bodies such as central banks struggled to monitor and manage bank counter-party risk during the crisis. Many made changes in their bank-related risk policies including altering the ways in which they set limits for bank counter-parties.

The risk of defaults by banks has significantly abated since the crisis as is evidenced by declines in spreads on bank debt and Credit Default Swaps (CDS). The reduction in such risks reflects the tightening of bank regulation since the crisis especially in the areas of capital and liquidity rules. But bank credit risk remains important and market participants should consider whether they have in place the infrastructure and procedures necessary for measuring bank credit risk in an accurate and timely fashion.

This note provides perspectives on different measures of credit risk applicable to bank exposures. We compare several approaches to, specifically (i) agency ratings, (ii) a combination of simple financial ratios suggested by regulators, (iii) Merton-style default probability estimates based on equity to liability ratios, and (iv) spreads on CDS.

The note is organised as follows. Section 1 describes the four credit risk indicators on which we focus. Section 2 gives information on the illustrative sample of banks we study. Section 3 presents results on how the risk measures have performed since the crisis. Section 4 concludes.

This paper was presented at the World Bank Executive Forum.

title: Integrating Carbon Capture into Copper Comminution: A Combined Techno-Economic Assessment and Life Cycle Analysis of GHG Emissions
affiliations: Purdue University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Virginia Tech, University of Kentucky and Purdue University

detail.title: Integrating Carbon Capture into Copper Comminution: A Combined Techno-Economic Assessment and Life Cycle Analysis of GHG Emissions

declarations.funderStatement: The research was supported by the U.S. Department of Energy ARPA-E Award No. DE-AR0001713.

detail.abstract: Copper production is highly energy-intensive, with comminution (crushing and grinding) accounting for a major portion of both energy use and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. This study evaluates the environmental and economic performance of integrating carbon capture into the copper comminution process through a combined Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) and Techno-Economic Analysis (TEA). The improved scenario introduces a CO 2 pretreatment step into the grinding circuit and is benchmarked against a conventional baseline process. The LCA results show that integrating CO 2 pre-treatment into the comminution process reduces grinding energy consumption from 3.1 to 2.6 kWh per kg copper. Combined with the embodied carbon emissions of the carbon capture system, the net greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reduction remains at 0.88-1.04 kg CO 2-eq per kg copper. From an economic perspective, the techno-economic analysis (TEA) indicates a unit cost saving of $0.12 per kg copper, corresponding to a 22.03-22.04% reduction in total grinding costs. These findings highlight the dual advantage of integrating carbon capture into comminution: achieving substantial GHG reductions while lowering operational costs.

title:
Consultation Response
An EU framework for simple, transparent and standardised securitisation
affiliations: Risk Control Limited

detail.title:
Consultation Response
An EU framework for simple, transparent and standardised securitisation
detail.abstract:
Risk Control thanks the European Commission for the opportunity to address the issues raised in the Consultation Document on an EU framework for simple, transparent and standardised securitisation published on 18th February 2015 (the “Consultation”).

Securitisation provides an important source of funding for bank and non-bank lenders. This is particularly significant in Europe where banks, because of the wider economic environment, face significant challenges in meeting scheduled Basel III increases in regulatory capital and liquidity ratios.

As the EU consultation notes, securitisation activity in Europe remains depressed. This is in contrast to the current experience in the US where securitisation new issue volumes have recovered. Identifying and, if possible, rectifying impediments to the revival of European securitisation is an important policy objective, in the view of many.

We believe that the defining by regulators of a category of High Quality Securitisation (HQS) transactions could contribute to the revival of securitisation activity in Europe, but only if the definition selected by the authorities serves as the basis for differential regulatory rules on capital and liquidity.

The Basel proposals for securitisation capital rules published in the December 2014 paper BCBS 303 are designed to cover a very broad set of securitisations. These range from simple, transparent securitisations of well-understood assets originated by tightly regulated banks, on the one hand, to opaque transactions with pool assets originated by unregulated entities and about which little information is available.

The bulk of the European market consists of securitisation of prime mortgages, SME loans, auto loans and card receivables originated by regulated banks (or well-established manufacturers in the case of auto loans). The banks involved typically organise their securitisations in a vertically integrated way with an important objective being that of raising funds for stable loan businesses. This market proved very robust in the face of a GDP stress that matched or exceeded in magnitude the stress experienced in the US.

title: Default Probability Risk and Securitisation Capital
affiliations: Risk Control Limited

detail.title: Default Probability Risk and Securitisation Capital
detail.abstract:
This paper develops a simple but rigorous approach to allowing for default probability risk in securitisation capital calculations. The approach consists of including additional random factors to describe risk in inputs, specifically default probabilities for pool loans. We show that the addition of such “parameter risk” translates into more conservative correlation assumptions for the asset correlations of the underlying loans.

Parameter risk is, hence, relevant for banks’ on-balance-sheet loans just as much as for securitisations secured on those loans. To the extent that parameter risk is correlated with systematic risk driving the bank’s wider portfolio, capital for loans should be increased. Securitisation capital, which depends on pool capital, should, in turn, be higher as well.

Parameter risk does not justify boosting securitisation capital for all the tranches in a deal beyond the level implied by prudent calculation of pool capital. It, therefore, does not provide an argument for deviations from capital neutrality under which the capital for all the tranches in a securitisation should equal that for the securitisation loan pool. (Reasons for non-neutrality includes the presence of agency costs created in complex, multi-agent securitisation processes.)

We believe that the Basel Committee allowed for parameter input risk in its original calibration of the Basel II capital risk weights for on-balance-sheet loans. Those involved in the calibration of Basel II were clearly aware that the correlation parameters employed in the Basel II risk weight functions were higher than those implied by statistical analysis of bank loan default data.

Our analysis shows that except where parameter risk implies higher pool capital, the impact on securitisation capital is relatively small. In particular, if parameter risk is correlated with intra-pool risk factors but is not systemic, then it justifies some limited shifting of capital towards more senior tranches. One might note that, if this latter type of parameter risk is present, the case for deduction of thin tranches attaching just below pool capital (a misguided and unjustified feature of current and proposed regulations) is even weaker.

title:
Stress Testing for an Asset Manager-Private Bank 
A Case Study
affiliations: Risk Control Limited

detail.title:
Stress Testing for an Asset Manager-Private Bank 
A Case Study
detail.abstract:
This note presents an illustrative case study of stress testing for an asset manager accomplished using Risk Control‟s Stress ControllerTM software. The calculations are performed for a notional UK asset manager that is also engaged in private banking operations. 

We show how the AUM (Assets under Management), balance sheet, P&L and key capital planning ratios of the private bank-asset manager group are affected by scenarios involving (i) customer loss and (ii) a UK recession. A set of equations is constructed to describe the evolution of the asset manager‟s financial statements. 

The AUM is modelled in a region- and asset-class-specific fashion. This permits the user to calibrate the distributions of the AUM across regions and to employ appropriate sensitivities of the AUM in each region to appropriate geographically specific market variables (equity indices, interest rates, exchange rates and commodity prices). 

The growth of each AUM class is forecast by taking into account (i) changes in relevant market prices and (ii) user-specified additional growth reflecting, for example, past trends in AUL market growth or anticipated marketing activities by the asset manager. The model allows the user to override forecasts by directly assuming particular levels of AUL growth for different components of the AUL asset class-region breakdown. 

Revenue in the form of fees depends on the AUM forecasts described above. Users are able also to specify fee rate dynamics directly if they wish, calibrating either the relative growth or the absolute level of the future fee rate. 

The results show how the asset manager‟s AUM size, revenue growth, loan impairment provisions and capital are boosted or depressed by the different stress scenarios. 

Note that the framework described here may be used either with coarse, public data to perform high level, top down stress testing or with highly granular internal data for bottom-up stress testing purposes. Financial statement modelling is highly flexible since equations may be written first in Excel, before being converted into scripts and then imported into the software for use at run-time to perform calculations.

title: Half of Michigan local law enforcement agencies say they are underfunded, while most local governments are satisfied with their appropriations
affiliations: University of Michigan at Ann Arbor - Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy and University of Michigan at Ann Arbor - Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy

detail.title: Half of Michigan local law enforcement agencies say they are underfunded, while most local governments are satisfied with their appropriations
detail.abstract: This report presents the views of Michigan's local government leaders, local chiefs of police, county sheriffs, and county prosecutors regarding funding for law enforcement agencies, including assessments of whether sheriff's offices and police departments receive the appropriate levels of funding, whether local officials would support pursuing new local millages or special assessments to fund law enforcement, and what each group's top priorities for potential new spending would be. These findings are based on statewide surveys of local government and law enforcement leaders in the spring 2024 wave of the Michigan Public Policy Survey (MPPS), with some comparison to data collected on the fall 2015 MPPS wave.

title: Securitization and the Value of Prepayment
affiliations: Virginia Tech - Department of Finance, Insurance, and Business Law

detail.title: Securitization and the Value of Prepayment
detail.abstract: Leveraging an exogenous shock to lenders' ability to securitize, I demonstrate that securitization allows lenders to offload prepaying loans, leading to increased credit for borrowers with a high propensity to prepay. I find that borrowers place value on the ability to prepay, as evidenced by sensitivity to prepayment fees and significant bunching around prepayment fee thresholds. Borrowers who prepay secure more favorable terms on subsequent loans and support greater job creation compared to those who repay loans on schedule. These findings underscore an often overlooked benefit of securitization: its ability to enhance credit access for high-quality borrowers who may lack a strong credit history but whose activities contribute to economic growth.

title: AI and Leveraging Strategies: Implications for Antitrust
affiliations: Cornell University - Law School

detail.title: AI and Leveraging Strategies: Implications for Antitrust
detail.abstract: In product markets that rely heavily on artificial intelligence (AI), firms both use data and generate data. For a multiproduct firm, the data generated by one product will often have spillover benefits on the firm's other AI-enabled products, increasing their quality. This presumptively benefits consumers and may encourage procompetitive coordination between complementary products or data sources. But these data spillovers also bolster incentives for anticompetitive leveraging strategies (e.g. tying), because excluding rivals in one market will indirectly raise the firm's profits in other markets as well. As a result, the spread of AI is likely to increase the prevalence and complexity of leveraging strategies in digital markets. This poses a challenge to American antitrust, whose treatment of leveraging conduct is fragmented across numerous doctrines, some of which are antiquated and economically unsound.

title: THE IMPACT OF SPECIAL AUTONOMY FUNDS AND NATURAL RESOURCE REVENUE-SHARING ON POVERTY IN ACEH VIA ECONOMIC GROWTH
affiliations: Universitas Mpu Tantular

detail.title: THE IMPACT OF SPECIAL AUTONOMY FUNDS AND NATURAL RESOURCE REVENUE-SHARING ON POVERTY IN ACEH VIA ECONOMIC GROWTH
detail.abstract: The Province of Aceh is a special autonomous region that has been receiving Special Autonomy Funds (DOK) since 2008. In addition to these funds, Aceh is endowed with abundant natural resources, which are expected to contribute to poverty alleviation and economic development. Nevertheless, Aceh continues to record one of the highest poverty rates in Indonesia. This study aims to empirically examine the direct and indirect effects of Special Autonomy Funds (DOK) and Natural Resource Revenue-Sharing Funds (DBHSDA) on poverty levels through the mediating role of economic growth in the regencies and municipalities of Aceh Province from 2017 to 2021. Using secondary data, this research applies panel data regression employing Fixed Effect and Random Effect Models-and path analysis to evaluate the hypothesized relationships. The results indicate that DOK has a positive and significant effect on economic growth but also a paradoxical positive effect on poverty, suggesting that the benefits of growth generated by DOK are not sufficiently inclusive. Economic growth is proven to significantly mediate the relationship between DOK and poverty, yet its indirect effect also tends to increase poverty levels. Meanwhile, DBHSDA shows no significant effect on either economic growth or poverty reduction, directly or indirectly, largely due to its relatively small size and unequal distribution among districts. These findings highlight the need for more strategic and equitable fund management, including stronger targeting of poverty alleviation programs and improved coordination between fiscal decentralization policies and inclusive development initiatives.

title: Focus on Women in Microfinance Institutions
affiliations: University of Agder

detail.title: Focus on Women in Microfinance Institutions
detail.abstract: We provide empirical evidence on focusing on women in microfinance and its consequences for microfinance institutions (MFIs). Based on a global dataset, the results indicate that a focus on women is associated with group-lending methods, international orientation, smaller loans, and non-commercial legal status. We find that a focus on women significantly improves repayment but does not enhance overall financial performance because of higher relative costs. Moreover, the higher relative costs do not stem from servicing women per se but from the smaller loans offered to women and the group-lending methodology practised by MFIs focusing on women.

title: Control Without Ownership: Governance of Nonprofit Hospitals
affiliations: Dartmouth College - Tuck School of Business, Dartmouth College - Tuck School of Business and University of Wisconsin Milwaukee

detail.title: Control Without Ownership: Governance of Nonprofit Hospitals
detail.abstract: We provide a comprehensive analysis of the governance structures of nonprofit hospitals and hospital systems. We study both the internal governance mechanisms (boards of directors, incentive contracts) and external mechanisms (market for corporate control, government oversight), with particular focus on the latter. Nonprofit boards are unusually large, include employee directors, exhibit less industry expertise among outside directors, and face weak external oversight. CEO pay and turnover are largely unresponsive to non-financial metrics such as quality or charity provision. The disciplinary role of the market for corporate control is also weaker in the nonprofit sector: nonprofits with poor financial performance are half as likely to be acquired or closed as for-profits, and weak performance on non-financial metrics has no effect on acquisitions or closures. Using time-series and cross-sectional variation in state oversight of nonprofits, we find that oversight strength explains a substantial portion of the gap in takeover rates between for-profits and nonprofits. We conclude that nonprofit governance structures lack the attributes traditionally associated with "good governance."

title: An American's Guide to the EU AI Act
affiliations: University of Colorado Law School, Yale University - Yale Information Society Project and UCLA School of Law

detail.title: An American's Guide to the EU AI Act
detail.abstract:
The EU AI Act entered into force in August 2024. The AI Act is long. It is complicated. It relies on a regulatory framework and institutions unfamiliar to many in the United States. But as the first omnibus AI regulation worldwide, it has the potential to have a vast influence on both practice and lawmaking.

In this Article, we provide the American’s Guide to the EU AI Act. At its core, the AI Act is structured on Europe’s product safety regime. It is aimed at governing AI systems through assigning them into risk tiers, and deploying bans, risk regulation, and self-regulation. But it also contains later-drafted provisions on general-purpose AI that depart from this framework, as well as multiple ad-hoc provisions and other regulatory strands.

We among other things point to the consequences of framing AI regulation as risk regulation and of constructing AI systems as products rather than bureaucratic processes. We describe the AI Act itself as a “legal exoskeleton,” with hard law built around the softer belly of technical standards. We identify the threats this poses for both substance and legitimacy, and the potential political ramifications of that design.

title: Self-Esteem and Rational Self-Handicapping
affiliations: Tennessee Technological University

detail.title: Self-Esteem and Rational Self-Handicapping

keywords: psychological game theory JEL classification: D90

detail.abstract: In order to protect their self-esteem, agents may create or seek out performance-inhibiting obstacles to avoid negative feedback about their ability. This behavior allows agents to attribute failures to self-imposed obstacles rather than to a lack of competence. Psychologists refer to this phenomenon as self-handicapping. In this paper, I model rational agents with preferences for self-esteem. This allows me to provide sufficient conditions under which these self-esteem concerned agents engage in rational self-handicapping behavior. I then consider the effects of self-esteem concerned agents in two policy relevant applications: education and tournaments. In education, designing an exam with noisier questions results in more studying by self-handicappers without discouraging other students. In tournaments, policies aimed at encouraging a particular group to show up to job interviews can result in strategic adjustment by the targeted group leading to lower overall attendance by that group.

title: Utility Structure, Pricing, and Energy Incentive Programs: Utility-level Analysis of Household Electricity Use in the Southeastern U.S
affiliations: Zhejiang University, Georgia Institute of Technology, Iowa State University - Department of Political Science, University of Tennessee, Knoxville - Center for Ultra-Wide-Area Resilient Electrical Energy Transmission Networks (CURENT) and Georgia Institute of Technology

detail.title: Utility Structure, Pricing, and Energy Incentive Programs: Utility-level Analysis of Household Electricity Use in the Southeastern U.S
detail.abstract: This study examines the relationship between utility-level characteristics-including ownership structure, electricity pricing, and various energy incentive programs-and residential electricity consumption over a hundred of utilities in the U.S Southeastern Georgia and North Carolina. Using a uniquely compiled dataset, we identify key factors influencing household electricity demand at the utility scale. We find that higher electricity rates and percent of adults with higher education are consistently associated with lower household consumption, while larger home sizes, use of electric heating, and higher income levels correspond to greater usage. Offerings of electric vehicle (EV) incentive programs are significantly linked to increased household electricity demand, even after controlling for the density of public EV charging infrastructure, suggesting their effectiveness in encouraging EV adoption and at-home charging. In contrast, the offerings of energy efficiency and renewable energy programs show no clear association with average electricity consumption. Utilities serving rural areas or governed as cooperatives tend to exhibit higher per-household electricity use, although these differences diminish when accounting for program availability and demographic variables. Our findings underscore the importance of integrating utility governance, program design, and pricing strategies to support equitable and efficient energy transitions, particularly in regions facing high energy burdens.

detail.abstract: The present investigation was carried out at the Research Block, Department of Crop Improvement, VCSG Uttarakhand University of Horticulture and Forestry, College of Forestry, Ranichauri, Tehri Garhwal, Uttarakhand. The experimental material comprised of 73 diverse faba bean genotypes. The crop of different genotypes was raised in an augmented design. Analysis of variance revealed among the checks were significant for six characters viz., significant for days to maturity, field emergence, plant height (cm), number of pods per plant, pod length (cm) and seed yield per plant (g). The correlation revealed that seed yield per plant showed positive correlation with pod length, while days to maturity exhibited highly significant and positive correlation with days to 50% flowering, number of pods per plant showed significant positive correlation with field emergence and highly significant and positive correlation with plant height, number of seeds per pod showed significant and positive correlation with plant height and 100 seed weight also showed highly significant and positive correlation with number of pods per plant. The results of path coefficient analysis using simple correlation coefficient showed that highest positive direct contribution towards seed yield per plant was exhibited by pod length followed by number of pods per plant and days to maturity.

detail.abstract: Blockchain technology is emerging as a transformative tool in the tourism industry, offering enhanced transparency, security, and operational efficiency. This review explores blockchain's applications in tourism, including secure booking systems, digital identity verification, loyalty programs, and sustainability tracking. By reducing intermediaries and improving trust, blockchain can streamline operations and meet consumer demand for ethical practices. However, the technology's adoption faces challenges such as technical scalability, high costs, regulatory uncertainties, and industry resistance. Current research frameworks, such as the Technology Acceptance Model and Theory of Planned Behavior, help to analyze factors influencing adoption, while quantitative and qualitative methodologies provide insights into stakeholder perspectives. Future opportunities for blockchain in tourism include integration with IoT and AI, establishing universal standards, and fostering consumer education. Addressing these challenges and seizing new opportunities can position blockchain as a foundational technology, supporting a more resilient, sustainable, and customer-centric tourism industry.

title: The Global Effects of Climateflation
affiliations: University of Alicante

detail.title: The Global Effects of Climateflation
detail.abstract: This paper examines the global transmission of temperature physical risks to imported commodity prices and domestic prices. I develop a novel measure of temperature shocks based on isolating extreme observations and conduct two empirical exercises. First, I estimate the global average impact of temperature shocks on commodity import prices disaggregated by raw materials and food. The country panel results show a sustained increase in prices, providing evidence of a new channel of temperature-induced imported inflation from commodities. Second, I show how foreign temperature shocks can weigh on import and domestic prices for the U.S. and key European economies. Temperature shock effects extend beyond a country's own borders, with a 1.7% peak increase in import prices in the U.S. Cross-border temperature spillovers also translate into higher producer price inflation (+0.9%), whereas the pass-through to consumer prices is more limited (+0.4%). Finally, I uncover asymmetries in the responses to the signs of the shock. Positive temperature shocks (heat waves) have larger short-term inflationary effects, affecting import prices more, while negative shocks (cold spells) are more pronounced for domestic inflation in the medium term. These findings highlight how the effects of extreme temperatures can be transmitted internationally through commodity markets, revealing unexpected sources of domestic inflation that challenge economies and central banks in maintaining price stability.

title: The Dynamics of Spectrum Cost in the Era of 4G and 5G and Its Impact on Mobile Network Development
affiliations: GSMA Intelligence, GSMA Intelligence and GSMA Intelligence

detail.title: The Dynamics of Spectrum Cost in the Era of 4G and 5G and Its Impact on Mobile Network Development

declarations.funderStatement: This study has been funded by GSMA.

detail.abstract: This research focuses on spectrum acquisition and its implications for mobile network operators (MNOs) and consumers in the period between 2014 and 2023. We performed a vast data collection on spectrum holdings and fees paid by close to 250 operators in nearly 100 countries. Mobile spectrum has increased consistently across all regions, driven by the rollout of 4G and 5G networks. Despite the enhanced functionality, average revenues per user have declined. These fundamentals have reduced the value of spectrum from the perspective of operators, and spectrum unit prices have declined in recent years. However, the overall cost of spectrum as a proportion of recurring revenue (the cost-to-revenue ratio) has increased, globally averaging 7.4% in 2023, up from 4.4% in 2014. This cost varies significantly across countries, from as little as 1% and up to 25% of operators' revenues. We attribute such vast differences in spectrum cost to different approaches taken by regulators and market dynamics. Through econometric analysis, we find that higher spectrum cost slows down network deployment and quality, with 10 pp higher spectrum cost to revenue ratio reducing network coverage by up to 2%, and reducing network speeds by up to 8%. On the other hand, we affirm positive impacts of making sufficient spectrum available, with 10% increase in available spectrum increasing network speeds by up to 3.8%. These findings point to spectrum policy as a key driver of network deployment strategies and infrastructure quality. Given the vast evidence on the economic benefits of connectivity, regulators should consider how pricing and timely release can maximise the benefits of spectrum to society.

title: The Kobor-Muralidhar Retirement and Education Plus Indices (TM) ©
affiliations: Georgetown University - McDonough School of Business and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Kobor-Muralidhar Retirement and Education Plus Indices (TM) ©
detail.abstract: The goal of investing for retirement is to secure a target level of income that maintains the individual's preretirement lifestyle. The goal for saving for a child's education is to secure the required annual fees required for their tuition and expenses. This paper describes a new set of proprietary affordability indices, the "Retirement Plus Indices" and "Education Plus Indices", that can track how the affordability changes for different cohorts for these two, or any other goals. The hope is that these indices can be maintained on a daily/weekly/monthly basis for any country, and thereby help individuals better plan for these goals and hold policy makers accountable as their actions affect the affordability of goals.

title: Integrating Explainable AI Techniques in Time Series Price Forecasting for Enhanced Interpretability and Decision-Making
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Integrating Explainable AI Techniques in Time Series Price Forecasting for Enhanced Interpretability and Decision-Making
detail.abstract: This research explores the integration of explainable AI (XAI) techniques within time series price forecasting models to enhance interpretability and support informed decision-making. As financial markets become increasingly complex, traditional forecasting methods often fall short in providing transparent insights into their predictions. This study proposes a hybrid framework that combines advanced machine learning algorithms with XAI methodologies, such as SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations). By applying these techniques to various time series datasets, including stock prices and commodity markets, we assess the impact of explainability on user trust and decision-making efficiency. Through comprehensive experiments, we demonstrate that integrating XAI not only improves the interpretability of predictions but also enhances the overall accuracy of forecasting models. Insights from user surveys further reveal that increased transparency leads to greater confidence in AI-driven decisions. The findings underscore the importance of explainability in financial forecasting, advocating for its adoption to bridge the gap between complex AI systems and user comprehension.

reference: E. Bonadio and C. Sganga (eds.), A Research Agenda on EU Copyright Law, Edward Elgar, 2025, 173-190
title: The future of the public domain
affiliations: SciencesPo

detail.title: The future of the public domain

publicationDetails.detailsText: E. Bonadio and C. Sganga (eds.), A Research Agenda on EU Copyright Law, Edward Elgar, 2025, 173-190

detail.abstract:
A greater attention and value have been attached to the public domain in the last decades by copyright scholars and lawmakers alike, with some attempts to protect it from encroachment and recapture through exclusive rights. This chapter retraces the evolution of the legal status of the public domain in copyright. Starting from the history of the notion of public domain and its presence, or rather absence, in copyright law, it insists on the precarity of the public domain as it does not receive any positive protection by law, lacks legal standing and is vulnerable to extension of copyright duration, as well as to other forms of reservation.

However, recent legal changes have sought to prohibit some enclosures of the public domain, notably the article 14 of the EU directive 2019/790 that rejects protection of reproductions of works of visual art whose copyright has expired, or the Vigeland decision of the EFTA Court that considered that the registration of a trademark in a public domain work could contradict public order. This emerging protection of public domain is encouraging though still very timid and incomplete, if one does not change its perception as a negative concept, as what is not protected by law. A more robust protection of public domain would need a reconceptualization of copyright into a more inclusive, relational and cultural model, instead of a strictly proprietarian and exclusivity-based paradigm. Within such a revised regime, allocating rights, privileges, entitlements and freedoms in creative resources and their many inputs to the cultural public sphere, public domain could be seen as a valuable cultural practice and be conferred some legal standing, in the form of collective and inclusive entitlements.

title: The Ethical Implications of Using Explainable AI in Price Forecasting: Balancing Transparency, Accuracy, and Market Manipulation Risks in Financial Predictions
affiliations: Bangladesh University, Bangladesh University of Business & Technology and Texas A & M University, Students

detail.title: The Ethical Implications of Using Explainable AI in Price Forecasting: Balancing Transparency, Accuracy, and Market Manipulation Risks in Financial Predictions
detail.abstract: The increasing reliance on artificial intelligence (AI) in financial markets necessitates a critical examination of its ethical implications, particularly concerning explainable AI (XAI) in price forecasting. This paper explores the delicate balance between transparency, accuracy, and the potential risks of market manipulation inherent in AI-driven predictions. While XAI enhances interpretability, enabling stakeholders to understand model decisions, it also raises concerns about the misuse of information and the strategic exploitation of insights for manipulative practices. Through a comprehensive analysis of case studies and ethical frameworks, this research highlights the dual-edged nature of XAI: its potential to foster trust and informed decision-making, alongside the risks of exacerbating market volatility and inequity. Ultimately, the paper advocates for a balanced approach that prioritizes ethical standards in the deployment of XAI, aiming to safeguard the integrity of financial markets while harnessing the benefits of advanced predictive technologies.

title: The Effects of Investment in Education and Training on Productivity Growth in the European Union
affiliations: Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI) Dublin and Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI)

detail.title: The Effects of Investment in Education and Training on Productivity Growth in the European Union
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the impact of on-the-job training on labour productivity, focusing on both the direct effects of training capital accumulation and its complementarity with other intangible capital assets. While previous research has highlighted the positive role of workplace training in enhancing productivity, we extend this literature by exploring how investments in training interact with other intangible assets such as software and data bases, innovation property, brand, and organizational capital. Using data from the EUKLEMS & INTANProd databases covering 17 industries across 27 EU countries, the UK, and the US between 1995 and 2021, we employ a difference-indifferences estimation approach within a production function framework augmented to include intangible capital. Our findings reveal that training significantly boosts labour productivity, with the effect being stronger in industries with higher training investment intensity. We also demonstrate that the complementarity between training and other intangible capital is most pronounced in business services and is mainly explained by the interaction between training and other firmspecific intangible assets such as branding and organisational capital.

title: From NGOs to Banks: Does Institutional Transformation Alter the Business Model of Microfinance Institutions?
affiliations: University of Agder

detail.title: From NGOs to Banks: Does Institutional Transformation Alter the Business Model of Microfinance Institutions?
detail.abstract: In the microfinance industry an increasing number of providers are undergoing an institutional transformation from NGO to a shareholder-owned and typically regulated financial entity. Little is known about the extent to which this transformation affects the way microfinance institutions (MFIs) conduct their business. Our results obtained by applying an event study methodology to 66 transformed MFIs suggest that portfolio yield is driven down by 3.9 percentage points due to transformation, indicating that clients get more favorable interest rates. MFIs are able to significantly cut down their operational expenses, of which 1.1 percentage points can be attributed to transformation. Other findings include a steep increase in commercial debt leverage and deposits, a significant decrease in the fluctuation of funding costs and a sharp rise in average loan size, often taken as an indicator for mission drift. Profitability in terms of ROA drops in the short term, while ROE is driven up in the medium to long run, suggesting a more shareholder-oriented attitude.

title: TDM, GenAI and the Copyright Three-Step Test
affiliations: Institute for Information Law (IViR), University of Amsterdam

detail.title: TDM, GenAI and the Copyright Three-Step Test
detail.abstract: In the debate on copyright exceptions permitting text and data mining (TDM) for the development of generative AI systems, the so-called "three-step test" has become a centre of gravity. The test serves as a universal yardstick for assessing the compatibility of domestic copyright exceptions with international copyright law. However, it is doubtful whether the international three-step test is applicable at all. Arguably, TDM copies fall outside the scope of the international right of reproduction and go beyond the ambit of the test's operation. Only if national or regional copyright legislation declares the test applicable, the question arises whether copyright exceptions supporting TDM for AI training constitute certain special cases that do not conflict with a work's normal exploitation and do not unreasonably prejudice legitimate author or rightsholder interests. As the analysis demonstrates, rules permitting TDM for AI training can satisfy all test criteria. An opt-out opportunity for copyright owners bans the risk of a conflict with a work's normal exploitation and an unreasonable prejudice from the outset. A clear focus on specific policy goals, such as the objective to support scientific research, adds conceptual contours that dispel concerns about incompliance. In the case of TDM provisions covering commercial AI development, equitable remuneration regimes can be introduced as a counterbalance to avoid an unreasonable prejudice.

title: The day after the dollar
affiliations: Institute of Economics and Industrial Engineering,  Siberian Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences and The Siberian Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences - Institute of Economics and Industrial Engineering

detail.title: The day after the dollar
detail.abstract: The international monetary system based on the US dollar as the world's dominant reserve currency has become in recent years risky and unreliable tool of international financial relations. In addition, confidence in the dollar is falling worldwide. These reasons lead to a transformation of the international currency system, primarily aimed at getting rid of the dominance of the US dollar. This transformation is still at the very beginning and it is unclear where it will come. The purpose of this paper is to consider possible directions of the transformation. This is not an attempt at forecasting, but an analysis of potential scenarios with assessments of the feasibility of their implementation. We are discussing a range of possible paths for transforming the international monetary system. One end of the range is the creation of a single supranational currency based on the reformation of Special Drawing Rights (SDR). The other end is the disintegration of the single currency system, which is partly already underway. In between is a return to the gold standard and the displacement of the US dollar by renminbi. However, an unpredictable option due the digitalization of currencies is also possible.

title: Are NGOs and cooperatives similar or different? A global survey using microfinance data
affiliations: University of Agder

detail.title: Are NGOs and cooperatives similar or different? A global survey using microfinance data
detail.abstract: Corporate governance remains fundamental to ensuring the social mission alongside the financial sustainability of microfinance institutions. One primary governance issue relates to the legal form used to perform microfinance activities. The sector deploys various forms including Banks, Non-Bank Financial Institutions, Cooperatives and NGOs, but each of them has unique features that lead to different orders of priorities and to distinct structures and mechanisms to pursue such a dual objective. This study compares the board governance model and the performance of cooperative organizations (COOPs) with nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) involved in microfinance. Using data on 352 rated microfinance institutions, the test results show that, compared to NGOs, COOPs have larger boards and a higher number of board meetings. However, NGOs have a greater percentage of international board members. The test on performance reveals that, whereas COOPs are more cost-efficient and charge lower interest rates, NGOs generally perform better in terms of social performance. However, the two organizational types do not perform differently in terms of profitability.

title: Mathematical Justification of Elitist Democracy: Formalization and Consistency Analysis of the baeKKim Model

detail.title: Mathematical Justification of Elitist Democracy: Formalization and Consistency Analysis of the baeKKim Model

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study is a theoretical work and does not involve human participants, therefore ethics approval was not required.

detail.abstract:
This study formalizes the baeKKim model, which mathematically reinterprets the relationship between citizens and the state through the concept of 'delegation' from a social contract perspective, and analyzes its internal consistency. In the baeKKim model, citizens delegate their freedom to the state as 'freedom as duty,' and the state functions as a sole reasoning entity that uses this delegated freedom as a resource to maximize overall social welfare. This paper defines the respective utility functions for citizens and the state. It analyzes the state's social welfare maximization problem using Lagrangian optimization, subject to the participation constraint that for a citizen to maintain delegation, the indirect utility gained through the state must be greater than the direct utility from acting independently.

The analysis reveals that 'freedom as right'—the indirect freedom redistributed by the state—has a zero-sum structure and inevitably reaches a state of Pareto optimality. Furthermore, 'delegation exit,' where a citizen withdraws delegation, is categorized into 'simple exit' and 'exit with new delegation,' with the latter identified as an effective means of exerting competitive pressure on the state. The existence of 'multiple governments,' which enables such re-delegation, is highlighted as a key institutional condition that makes delegation exit a realistic option.

In conclusion, this study argues that the legitimacy of elitist democracy is founded on the voluntary delegation of citizens. This legitimacy is secured through the institutional guarantee of paths for delegation exit and re-delegation, as well as the transparent establishment of the social welfare function's values. The model's analysis provides concrete institutional design principles and policy implications for elitist democracy to become a rational and stable form of governance that promotes citizens' freedom and welfare.

title: Take-Rates in Means-Tested Social Programs: Beyond Participation Costs
affiliations: Georgetown University, Georgetown University - McDonough School of Business and Georgetown University - McDonough School of Business

detail.title: Take-Rates in Means-Tested Social Programs: Beyond Participation Costs
detail.abstract: Economists and policymakers often question why many eligible households do not enroll in means-tested social programs. Traditional studies highlight information costs, transaction costs, and stigma, which we refer to as "participation costs" as main factors for under-enrollment. We extend this perspective by evaluating the impact of private-sector providers and third-party outreach partners on participation rates. Our analysis focuses on the $14.2 billion Affordable Connectivity Program (ACP), which was aimed at increasing broadband adoption among low-income households. Using novel county-level data, we examine program take-rates and confirm the significance of not only traditional participation costs but also demonstrate the ability of local government capacity and private-sector engagement with the ACP to enhance county-level take-rates. These results underscore the importance of federal-local and public-private partnerships as effective policy tools for improving means-tested program success. Our results also fail to identify an FCC grants program, which was designed to stimulate ACP participation, as effective. We explore the possible reasons for this outcome.

title: The APAC State of Open Banking and Open Finance Report
affiliations: University of Cambridge - Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance, University of Cambridge, Judge Business School, Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance, Students, University of Cambridge - Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance, University of Cambridge - Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance, Independent and Cambridge Centre for Alternative Finance, Cambridge Judge Business School, University of Cambridge

detail.title: The APAC State of Open Banking and Open Finance Report
detail.abstract: The APAC State of Open Banking and Open Finance Report assesses how open banking and open finance are being adopted across 16 jurisdictions in the Asia-Pacific (APAC) region, including Australia, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, the Philippines, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand, and Vietnam. The study reviews differences in implementation between jurisdictions within APAC, identifies regional trends, compares them with global trends, and investigates their underlying causes. Additionally, the report features detailed case studies from 9 jurisdictions within the region. The primary objective is to offer policymakers, regulators, and industry stakeholders with a timely, evidence-based understanding of open banking and open finance in APAC, concentrating on governance strategies, data sharing, and key stakeholder challenges.

title: The End of Sticky Prices and Menu Costs
affiliations: Stanford University

detail.title: The End of Sticky Prices and Menu Costs
detail.abstract: Sticky prices and menu costs have long been foundational to New Keynesian macroeconomic models, providing the key nominal friction for monetary non-neutrality. However, this paper argues that the empirical and theoretical relevance of price stickiness has diminished. Drawing on both micro and macro evidence, I document the increasing frequency of price adjustments, the rise of e-commerce and dynamic pricing, I document the growing role of information frictions and wage stickiness in driving real rigidities. The shift away from sticky price models toward frameworks emphasizing sticky wages or informational and behavioral frictions challenges the centrality of menu costs in modern macroeconomics. This evolution invites a reevaluation of monetary transmission mechanisms and model calibration in dynamic stochastic general equilibrium (DSGE) frameworks.

title: From Promise to Performance: Reforming Blended Finance for Scale
affiliations: Columbia University - Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment, Columbia University - Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment and Columbia University - Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment

detail.title: From Promise to Performance: Reforming Blended Finance for Scale

detail.abstract: Blended finance has the potential to help close the sustainable development financing gap. Strategically combining public and philanthropic capital to unlock private investment, it has proven to be an effective tool to de-risk impact investments. But without bold, structural reform, it risks remaining a niche tool – promising in theory, underperforming in practice. Drawing on over 65 expert interviews and in-depth analysis, this report from the Columbia Center on Sustainable Investment (CCSI) maps the systemic barriers preventing blended finance from operating at scale, and outlines a practical path forward. With bold leadership and coordinated reform, blended finance can become a mainstream channel for sustainable investment at scale.

title: Employer Concentration and Wages: Evidence from Large Firms' Hiring Shocks
affiliations: UCLA Anderson School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Sloan School of Management, Lightcast and Bureau of Labor Statistics

detail.title: Employer Concentration and Wages: Evidence from Large Firms' Hiring Shocks
detail.abstract: We estimate the effect of increases in employer concentration on wages, using a new instrument for employer concentration based on changes in large firms' national hiring patterns. We measure employer concentration over mobility-adjusted labor markets: clusters of local occupations identified through asymmetric mobility patterns (using new, highly granular data on occupational mobility from 16 million resumes). We find that increased employer concentration causally reduces wages: moving from the median to the 95th percentile of employer concentration as experienced by workers lowers wages by 4 log points. Overall, we estimate that more than one in six U.S. workers face wage suppression of 2.5% or more as a result of above-median employer concentration. The effects of employer concentration are particularly pronounced in healthcare occupations.

title: Webometric Analysis of Twitter Hashtags in Indian Railway: A Comprehensive Study

detail.title: Webometric Analysis of Twitter Hashtags in Indian Railway: A Comprehensive Study
detail.abstract: This study presents a comprehensive webometric analysis of Twitter hashtags related to Indian Railways, aimed at understanding patterns of digital engagement, user sentiment, and thematic trends in public discourse. Using a dataset comprising 45,000 tweets collected over the year 2023, the research examines hashtag frequency, co-occurrence networks, sentiment distribution, source types, language usage, and platform access. The findings reveal that #indianrailways dominates the conversation, followed by employment-related hashtags such as #railwaynewrojgardo, which exhibit high negative sentiment, indicating public dissatisfaction regarding job opportunities. In contrast, tourism-related hashtags like #CharDhamYatra generate higher engagement and more neutral to positive sentiment. Analysis also shows that Twitter is primarily accessed through mobile devices, with most tweets originating from Android platforms and composed in English or Hinglish. The study further highlights the significant role of public-generated content in driving discussions on recruitment, services, and passenger grievances. By integrating sentiment analysis and co-occurrence mapping, this research provides actionable insights for enhancing Indian Railways' digital communication strategies and improving public service responsiveness through social media. The findings contribute to the broader understanding of webometric applications in public sector transportation systems.

A total of 154 articles were obtained from the Scopus and WOS database through a rigorous review employed several analyses in the data analysis, including studying the number of studies per year, the distribution of studies by authors, countries, and the trend topics. The research findings indicate a notable rise in the number of studies conducted since 2017, particularly in the healthcare sector. Additionally, emerging research areas include product liability, strict liability, crime, and civil liability. Concerns regarding bias, malpractice, and decisionmaking, are the underdeveloped areas of AI legislation have highlighted the need for further study in relation to liability. When it comes to the number of publications, the USA garners attention, following Italy, Brazil, and Germany. The authors primarily focused on the countries involved in their research. The findings suggest that the increasing focus on liability in Artificial Intelligence research will continue to drive progress in developing better policies and trustworthy AI.

detail.abstract: Following a 2018 Supreme Court ruling that overturned the prohibition on sports betting in most states, 38 states have since passed laws legalizing sports gambling. Although many studies analyze the costs of legalized sports betting, most ignore the fact that benefits also exist. This study examines both the costs and benefits of legalizing sports betting. With structured regulatory oversight, it appears that legalized sports betting is a net positive.

detail.title: The New Digital Divide
detail.abstract: We build and analyze new metrics of digital usage that leverage telemetry data collected by Microsoft during operating system updates across forty million Windows devices in U.S. households. These measures of US household digital usage are much more comprehensive than those made available through any existing commercial or government survey. We construct representations of devices in ZIP codes and find evidence of significant variation in usage reflecting an urban-rural divide. We also show the existence of substantial disparities in usage even within narrowly defined Metropolitan Statistical Areas. Income and education correlate with these observed differences. These effects are large and suggest digital literacy gaps that extend beyond the availability of essential IT infrastructure at the local level. These findings call for interventions beyond the traditional focus on infrastructure access and address usage and skills development. The indices are made publicly available to support future research.

detail.title: Balancing Rights and Governance: A Comparative Analysis of Open Disclosure Frameworks in Australia and New Zealand

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no financial relationships of relevance. The author has worked in clinical and clinical governance roles in both Australia and New Zealand.
declarations.funderStatement: No specific funding was provided for this project.

detail.abstract:
Aim: To comprehensively analyse the open disclosure frameworks in Australia and New Zealand, identifying their strengths, weaknesses, and trade-offs, and to propose a hybrid model integrating best practices.

Method: This qualitative comparative policy analysis systematically reviewed key policy documents from Australia (e.g., Australian Open Disclosure Frameworks, NSQHS Standards) and New Zealand (e.g., Guidance on Open Disclosure Policies, Code of Health and Disability Services Consumers' Rights). Data extraction focused on principles, processes, governance, legal aspects, and implementation strategies. Four core theoretical frameworks-Institutional Theory, Regulatory Governance, Ethics of Care, and Implementation Science-were applied to analyse the extracted data. The analysis involved thematic coding, cross-country comparison through each theoretical lens, and synthesis to identify trade-offs and inform a refined hybrid model.

Result: Australia's framework, embedded in national safety standards, emphasizes systemwide governance and accreditation, offering flexibility but risking implementation variability. New Zealand's model, legally mandated under consumer rights legislation, prioritizes individual accountability and patient rights, ensuring strong enforcement but potentially fostering a compliance-driven culture. Key differences emerged in legal specificity, enforcement mechanisms, and the practicalities of implementation. The analysis highlighted the critical role of ethical considerations, workforce capacity, and organizational readiness for effective open disclosure.

Conclusion: Both Australian and New Zealand open disclosure frameworks offer valuable insights into balancing systemic governance and consumer rights. A hybrid approach, integrating Australia's focus on systemic learning with New Zealand's robust legal mandate for patient rights and explicit ethical considerations, could enhance healthcare quality and transparency. Future research should empirically evaluate the practical implementation and outcomes of such hybrid models.

title: Risk Premia in the Bitcoin Market
affiliations: Erasmus University Rotterdam (EUR) - Erasmus School of Economics, Princeton University - Bendheim Center for Finance, Humboldt University of Berlin -  IRTG 1792 "High Dimensional Nonstationary Time Series" and Southwestern University of Finance and Economics (SWUFE)

detail.title: Risk Premia in the Bitcoin Market
detail.abstract: We analyze the first and second moment risk premia in the Bitcoin market based on options and realized returns and contrast them to the premia embedded in the main US stock index market. First, Bitcoin is much more volatile and has a higher variance risk premium than the S&P 500. By decomposing the return premium into different regions of the return state space, we find that while most of the S&P 500 equity premium comes from mildly negative returns, the corresponding negative Bitcoin returns (between three and one standard deviations) account for only one-third of the total Bitcoin premium (BP). Further, applying a novel clustering algorithm to a collection of estimated Bitcoin option-implied risk-neutral densities, we find that risk premia vary over time as a function of two distinct market volatility regimes. The low-volatility regime implies a relatively high share of BP attributable to positive returns and a high Bitcoin Variance Risk Premium (BVRP). In high-volatility states, the BP attributable to positive and negative returns is more balanced, and the BVRP is lower. These results suggest Bitcoin investors are more concerned about variance and upside risk in a low-volatility regime.

detail.abstract: This paper introduces a framework for evaluating R&D intensity optima through joint valuation and profit effect consideration. I construct a static framework and dynamic lifecycle model and use panel firm fixed-effects regressions across 3,204 firm-year observations (2020-2024) to confirm key hypotheses: the R&D-valuation relationship is consistently non-linear, varying significantly by sector, risk, and firm size. Results suggest unique pre/post-inflection relationships, sectoral optimums, and widespread inefficiencies in U.S. public firm innovation capital allocation. This study serves to expand understanding of R&D dynamics, help investors evaluate innovation strategies/mispricing, highlight market inefficiencies for policymakers, and aid corporate allocators in maximizing R&D return. Forthcoming in the Columbia Economic Review, Vol. 2025, Columbia University.

detail.abstract: This article examines the evolution of the concept of geographical selectivity in EU State aid law, particularly in the context of taxation. It focuses on the development and application of the sufficient autonomy test as established by the CJEU in the landmark Azores judgment and further refined in the UGT-Rioja and Gibraltar cases. The article begins by outlining the challenges posed by regional tax measures that may confer selective advantages. The article then analyses how the three criteria of the sufficient autonomy test were applied in the Azores, UGT-Rioja and Gibraltar cases. The article concludes that while the sufficient autonomy test provides a structured approach to assessing geographical tax selectivity, it does not completely eliminate legal uncertainty. Ambiguities remain, especially in interpreting the autonomy criteria and their application in diverse constitutional contexts. Nonetheless, the test represents a pragmatic compromise between the EU’s objective of preventing distortions of competition and the Member States’ fiscal sovereignty.

detail.title: Research and Application of Comprehensive Evaluation Model of Campus Safety Culture Based on Game Theory-Regret Theory
detail.abstract: To enhance the scientific and objective evaluation of campus safety culture, thereby reducing the risk of campus accidents and improving the overall level of safety culture, this study developed a evaluation index system of campus safety culture from five levels: safety physical culture, safety institutional culture, safety conceptual culture, safety behavioral culture, and safety environmental culture. The campus safety culture evaluation index system employs the ordinal relationship analysis method (G1 method) and the anti-entropy weight method to determine the subjective and objective weights of the indicators, respectively. Additionally, game theory is utilized to compute the comprehensive weights of these indicators. Ultimately, the established comprehensive evaluation model of campus safety culture, founded on game theory and regret theory, was applied to assess the safety culture at universities in Ganzhou. The results show that this evaluation model is suitable for campus safety culture evaluation and provides feasible paths for  for such evaluations.

title: Addressing Privacy Challenges Faced by China's Gig Workers: Lessons from GDPR in EU

detail.title: Addressing Privacy Challenges Faced by China's Gig Workers: Lessons from GDPR in EU
detail.abstract: In the context of the 'gig economy', casual workers are being assigned and monitored by platform companies, and there is a conflict between the management rights of platform companies and the privacy rights of gig workers, who are facing serious privacy risks. China's Personal Information Protection Law ('PIPL'), which was introduced in 2021, explicitly requires employers to protect the privacy of employees in the course of their work, but as gig workers are not classified as employees under Chinese labor laws, it aggravates the conflict between the management rights of platform companies and workers' privacy. Drawing on the EU's General Data Protection Regulation ('GDPR'), this paper proposes the need to clarify the concept of 'necessity' in data collection, expands the scope of applicable subjects in PIPL, and ensures that consent based on true intent is obtained from gig workers. At the same time, it is recommended that communication be strengthened through trade unions to balance the interests between platform companies and gig workers, so as to achieve a dynamic balance and promote the sustainable development of the platform/gig economy.

title: The Carbon Footprints of Returning to Work: Office Leasing and Commuting Impacts

detail.title: The Carbon Footprints of Returning to Work: Office Leasing and Commuting Impacts
detail.abstract: The shift toward remote and hybrid work (RHW) has reduced overall office leasing activity and sparked new questions about the future of urban office space. This study investigates how the sustainable and urban characteristics of office spaces moderate office leasing decisions in the new RHW era, along with their downstream effects. Using a proprietary dataset covering the Canadian office market after 2020one of the world's most stabilized RHW environments-we combine leasing, sustainability, and mobility data to explore how organizational and employee preferences shape space utilization and environmental outcomes. Findings show that sustainability certifications-both at the asset and landlord level-have cemented their role in the modern definition of high-quality office buildings, and that the strongest demand for office space is situated in vibrant urban areas. Despite the reduced commuting associated with RHW, mobility patterns reveal that workers are commuting longer distances to reach sustainable and urban offices, suggesting that these attributes are highly valued. Taken together, investment into creating sustainable and urban office environments leads to not only strong leasing activity in the building, but also enhanced vibrancy for the surrounding community. Yet there may be unintended consequences associated with the resulting increase in commuting distances, raising concerns about emissions, congestion, and quality of life.

detail.abstract: When imposing the “reciprocal” tariffs set forth in Executive Order 14,257, the President is negotiating and entering into foreign trade agreements for the purpose of opening foreign markets for U.S. products. Since 1934, Congress has specifically and repeatedly granted the President the authority to proclaim tariff modifications without congressional approval in precisely such a context, but that authority last expired on July 1, 2021. Regardless of whether the power to regulate importation under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 encompasses the power to impose tariffs, that power, which is ambiguous, should not be interpreted to allow the President to do what Congress has disallowed the President to do under other unambiguous statutes regulating the very same presidential action, when Congress allowed the President’s tariff proclamation authority to expire.

title: Macroeconomic Impact of External Shocks: A Review of Literature

detail.title: Macroeconomic Impact of External Shocks: A Review of Literature
detail.abstract: External shocks remain a key driver of macroeconomic outcomes, especially in emerging and developing economies that depend heavily on international trade and capital flows. To design effective policy responses, policymakers must understand the origins, transmission mechanisms, and macroeconomic variables most affected by these shocks. This paper systematically reviews the theoretical and empirical studies examining the impact of these shocks on the domestic macroeconomy. The review identifies a diverse set of theoretical perspectives that together explain how different shocks affect the macroeconomy. Empirically, the literature shows that the magnitude and direction of the impact vary depending on the origin of the shock, the structural characteristics of the economy, the policy regimes, and the degree of external dependency. The review reveals important gaps in the literature, particularly concerning sub-Saharan African economies, stressing the need for further context-specific empirical research.

English Abstract: This chapter proposes a conceptual framework that links the regulatory transformation of the welfare state with the transformation of social citizenship. It argues that in the era of the regulatory welfare state, where the state provides fewer services directly and instead focuses on funding and regulating non-state providers, there is a need to rethink the foundations of social citizenship. The chapter identifies three core dimensions of social citizenship that are challenged by this shift: the status of social rights, the modes of access to rights, and the patterns of accountability between the state, providers, and service users. It shows how the regulatory configuration of welfare governance redefines these dimensions and creates both new opportunities and risks for citizenship. By conceptualizing regulation not merely as a technical tool but as a political and normative field, the chapter offers a lens through which to analyze the evolving relationship between the individual and the state in contemporary welfare regimes.

title: Weather Impacts on Home Insurance Losses: Evidence from British Columbia

detail.title: Weather Impacts on Home Insurance Losses: Evidence from British Columbia
detail.abstract: Extreme weather increasingly threatens homes, however, the magnitude of impacts on insurance losses remain uncertain. Here we link proprietary home-insurance claims from British Columbia, Canada, with administrative property records and high-resolution temperature and precipitation data to quantify the effects of weather on insurance losses. We show that a onestandard-deviation rise in monthly precipitation (+130 mm) increases average claim payouts by 17% and doubles the number of claims (+130%). A comparable one standard deviation increase in average temperatures (+5C) raises claim frequency by roughly 50%, though its effect on claim severity is imprecise. Rolling-window estimates and allowing for linear time trends in weather effects reveal little evidence of adaptation over our sample from 2001-2021. These findings suggest insurers should recalibrate risk models and pricing approaches to account for sharply rising claim frequency under evolving climate patterns.

detail.abstract: Over the past two decades, industrial organization (IO) research within agricultural and resource economics (ARE) has gained substantial influence. We document this shift using state-of-the-art AI models and a targeted survey of IO scholars. Drawing on 18,809 articles published in the top 10 ARE journals (1975-2024) and 8,284 articles from five leading IO journals, we trace changes in thematic focus, methodological approaches, and citation trends. A central finding is that IO research in ARE has experienced a marked rise in scholarly influence since the early 2000s. We explore potential drivers of this trend and highlight areas where IO scholarship is especially uniquely positioned to shape future research. Beyond the substantive contributions, we demonstrate how AI tools can be used to map the intellectual evolution of economic subfields at scale.

detail.title: Uncertainty-Aware Decision Support System for Incident-Responsive Ramp Metering Using Multi-Stage Fuzzy Logic
detail.abstract: This study presents an Uncertainty-Aware Decision Support System (UA-DSS) for incident-responsive ramp metering in urban expressways. The system integrates a multi-stage fuzzy logic controller (MS-FLC) with a fuzzy-defined risk evaluation mechanism to address real-time decision-making under data uncertainty. A linguistic Risk Factor is formulated based on incident severity, time-of-day, and control effectiveness, enabling adaptive control decisions through fuzzy inference. Simulation experiments using a representative network and diverse incident scenarios demonstrate that UA-DSS significantly outperforms conventional strategies such as ALINEA and non-risk-adaptive MS-FLC. The proposed approach shows strong robustness, improving mainline traffic flow and minimizing ramp queue spillback, even under delayed or imprecise input conditions. This work contributes to the field of intelligent transportation systems by providing a practical and interpretable AI-driven traffic control architecture, aligned with EAAI’s emphasis on engineering applications of fuzzy logic and real-time decision support

detail.abstract: In this paper, we investigate the necessary conditions for applying the bootstrap method in propensity score matching (PSM) when modeling various economic scenarios like public subsidy, online advertisement, and healthcare within the framework of causal inference. We provide mathematical reasoning to explain the different mechanisms of full-sample matching and bootstrap subsampling matching that lead to changes in performance. We define the utilization rate and investigate the conditions where bootstrap subsampling enhances the estimate of the average treatment effect on the treated group (ATT). In addition, we propose a comparable weighted subsampling method and evaluate these methodologies against a baseline method regarding their ATT estimates. We conduct extensive simulations under two different data generation frameworks (threshold rule with linear regression and probability assignment with logistic regression models). Within each framework, we perform diverse feature settings, including univariate and multivariate, single-confounder, and multi-confounder. Our findings reveal the conditions where each method (baseline, full-sample, bootstrap, and weighted) can outperform others. These findings can guide researchers and analysts to select the most appropriate matching method for future observational studies.

detail.title: Alcohol, Marijuana and Education
detail.abstract: We analyze transitions into alcohol and marijuana use alongside grade progression using data from the 1997 cohort of the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth. Employing a discrete-time hazard framework, we account for correlated unobserved heterogeneity that jointly in uences all transitions. Our model estimates the e ects of initiating alcohol and marijuana use on educational attainment, allowing these e ects to vary by age of initiation. Average marginal e ects suggest that marijuana use reduces the probability of progressing to the next grade by 10.2 percentage points when initiated before age 16, and by 4 percentage points when initiated after age 15. For alcohol, the corresponding e ects are -4.5 and -5.8 percentage points, respectively. Our results further demonstrate that unobserved heterogeneity plays a more substantial role in explaining grade transitions than observed characteristics, highlighting the importance of accounting for latent factors in models of educational and behavioral outcomes.

detail.title: Divisia Broad Money, Financial Regulation and the Welfare Cost of Inflation
detail.abstract: Much recent research on the welfare cost of inflation was stimulated by a claim that a 10% inflation imposes a welfare cost of nearly 1% of real income. Most research uses the standard measures of money, however there are potential gains from adopting the Divisia approach for estimating the welfare costs of inflation, as this should better capture the flow of monetary services when standard monetary aggregates include interest bearing close substitutes for money. However, there is a problem if the Divisia aggregate does not track all forms of near money. This paper argues that the welfare gain calculated using Divisia is biased upwards by the exclusion of Money Market Deposit Accounts from the Divisia index in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
